Utilize the Gap Effect: Incorporate random intervals of doing nothing within study sessions. This approach, backed by Huberman, suggests taking around 30 such breaks every hour. However, the implementation can be flexible, emphasizing natural breaks when you feel a slowdown in focus or energy.

Get Alert: Activation of the body and mind is crucial before diving into learning. Huberman recommends taking approximately 25 deep breaths to increase alertness. Alternatives like going for a walk or engaging in exercise can also serve the same purpose, depending on individual preference and circumstances.

Get Focused: To enhance focus, Huberman suggests picking a point in the room to stare at for 30 to 60 seconds without entertaining other thoughts. This simple exercise can significantly improve concentration and facilitate a smoother transition into intensive study or work.

Limit Study Sessions: Aim for a maximum of 90 minutes per study session. This timeframe aligns with the typical duration most people can maintain intense focus. It‚Äôs advisable to set a minimum goal, such as 60 minutes, to ensure productive learning periods.

Incorporate Non-Sleep Deep Rest (NSDR): After studying, engage in NSDR practices like meditation or short naps (around 20 minutes) to consolidate learning. If time is limited, even a brief period of rest (1 to 10 minutes) can be beneficial. This is particularly effective for both physical skills and cognitive learning, aiding in memory retention and skill acquisition.

Sleep: Adequate sleep following learning activities is vital. It plays a significant role in consolidating memories and enhancing learning outcomes.

Personal Adaptation: Huberman emphasizes the importance of tailoring these strategies to fit individual routines and preferences. Focusing techniques and taking brief breaks during study sessions were highlighted as particularly effective personalized strategies.

Three things;
1) Full range of motion on shoulder press movements, although it does stimulate more of your deltoids, that lower portion of the range is a high risk area. For anyone prone to rotator cuff injuries, which most of us are, the greater majority of trainers and bodybuilders recommend to always stick to 90 degree angle.
2) Another method to reduce usage of your traps while doing side lateral raises; roll your shoulders slightly forward and give a slightly more aggressive bend to your elbows. This will emphasize the side deltoids and reduce trap activation.
3) I agree with practically everything else in this video. But I am incredibly happy to see mentioning of high volume being more advantageous. So sick of this new trend promoted by lazy people to do 'low volume, high intensity' .. especially considering they're likely not doing 'high intensity' like they believe. Most of the recent studies have all been agreeing that high volume, with progressive overload, and high intensity, is the most effective way to build mass. Some even saying 20-30 sets per week being optimal. But it really all boils down to your sleep hygiene and nutrition. Poor sleep and poor nutrition equals poor recovery. The thumbnail is very misleading. There's nothing wrong with doing 12 reps, if that's the number you reach when going 1-2 reps short of failure. Numerous studies have shown that you can do as many as 30 reps, and still build the same amount of muscle as someone doing far fewer reps (but heavier). The important key is that you do enough reps till you get very, very close to failure in each set.

Also, increasing the weight is not the only way to implement progressive overload. By repping out till you get to failure or 1-2 reps short of failure, and you're doing everything else correctly, you will naturally be able to do more and more reps. That challenges the muscle and overloads it progressively without going for heavier weight. Of course, this is to a certain extent. If the rep count starts to go above 30, then gains start being left on the table.
